title: Risk for Injury Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for patients at risk for injury, focusing on assessment, prevention strategies, and environmental modifications to promote safety and prevent harm.

assessments.title: Risk Factor Assessment
points: Evaluate sensory-perceptual deficits (vision, hearing, tactile)
Assess cognitive status including orientation, memory, and judgment
Evaluate mobility status including balance, gait, and use of assistive devices
Assess medication regimen for medications that increase fall risk
Evaluate environmental hazards in patient area
assessments.description: Comprehensive risk assessment identifies factors that contribute to injury risk and guides preventive interventions

assessments.title: Fall Risk Assessment
points: Complete standardized fall risk assessment tool (Morse Fall Scale, STRATIFY, etc.)
Assess history of previous falls including circumstances and outcomes
Evaluate orthostatic blood pressure changes
Assess footwear and clothing for safety
Evaluate toileting patterns and ability to request assistance
assessments.description: Standardized fall risk assessment helps quantify risk level and determine appropriate preventive measures

assessments.title: Environmental Assessment
points: Evaluate lighting adequacy in all areas used by patient
Assess floor surfaces for slip/trip hazards
Check furniture stability and appropriateness
Evaluate bathroom safety including grab bars and non-slip surfaces
Assess accessibility of call light and personal items
assessments.description: Environmental assessment identifies modifiable hazards that can be addressed to reduce injury risk

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Risk for Injury related to sensory-perceptual alterations, cognitive impairment, and environmental hazards
Risk for Falls related to altered mobility and environmental hazards

goals.statement: Patient will remain free from injury during hospitalization
indicators: Demonstrates use of call light for assistance

goals.statement: Patient/caregiver will demonstrate knowledge of injury prevention strategies prior to discharge
indicators: Demonstrates proper use of assistive devices

interventions.title: Fall Prevention
actions: Implement fall precautions according to facility protocol
Orient patient to environment and location of call light
Ensure bed is in lowest position with brakes locked when patient is in bed
Use bed/chair alarms for high-risk patients
Assist with toileting on regular schedule
Ensure adequate lighting, especially at night
rationales: Standardized precautions provide consistent approach to fall prevention
Orientation reduces confusion and promotes independence
Low bed height minimizes injury potential if fall occurs
Alarms alert staff to unauthorized movement
Scheduled toileting reduces urgency-related falls
Adequate lighting improves visibility and reduces trip hazards
specialConsiderations: Avoid physical restraints when possible as they may increase injury risk
Consider 1:1 observation for extremely high-risk patients

interventions.title: Environmental Management: Safety
actions: Remove clutter and obstacles from walkways
Secure electrical cords away from traffic areas
Ensure non-slip surfaces in bathroom and shower
Keep frequently used items within reach
Recommend appropriate footwear (non-slip, proper fit)
Evaluate need for assistive devices and ensure proper use
rationales: Clear pathways reduce trip hazards
Secured cords prevent tripping
Non-slip surfaces reduce fall risk in wet areas
Accessible items reduce need for reaching or bending
Proper footwear improves stability and traction
Correctly used assistive devices improve mobility safety

evaluations.statement: Has the patient remained free from injury?
Does patient/caregiver demonstrate knowledge of injury prevention?
expectedOutcomes: Demonstrates proper use of assistive devices
Identifies environmental modifications needed at home
Describes plan for continued safety after discharge

title: Fatigue Management
description: A structured care plan for managing fatigue in patients with acute or chronic conditions, focusing on energy conservation, activity pacing, and addressing underlying causes.

assessments.title: Fatigue Assessment
points: Assess fatigue severity using standardized scale (0-10 or Fatigue Severity Scale)
Evaluate pattern of fatigue including onset, duration, and alleviating/aggravating factors
Assess impact on activities of daily living and quality of life
Evaluate sleep patterns including quality, duration, and disruptions
Assess for psychological factors contributing to fatigue (depression, anxiety)
assessments.description: Comprehensive fatigue assessment helps identify patterns, severity, and impact on function to guide interventions

assessments.title: Physical Assessment
points: Assess vital signs including orthostatic blood pressure changes
Evaluate nutritional status and hydration
Assess activity tolerance and exercise capacity
Evaluate for signs of anemia or other physiological causes of fatigue
Review medication regimen for drugs that may contribute to fatigue
assessments.description: Physical assessment helps identify underlying physiological causes of fatigue that may be treatable

assessments.title: Functional Assessment
points: Evaluate ability to perform ADLs independently
Assess energy expenditure during various activities
Evaluate home environment for factors increasing energy demands
Assess availability of support systems
Evaluate current activity and rest patterns
assessments.description: Functional assessment helps identify areas where energy conservation techniques can be implemented

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Fatigue related to physiological states, psychological states, and situational factors as evidenced by verbalization of overwhelming lack of energy and inability to maintain usual routines
Activity Intolerance related to imbalance between oxygen supply and demand as evidenced by abnormal heart rate or blood pressure response to activity
relatedFactors: Imbalance between oxygen supply and demand
definingCharacteristics: Abnormal heart rate or blood pressure response to activity
Verbal report of fatigue or weakness

goals.statement: Patient will report decreased fatigue levels and improved energy
indicators: Reports fatigue reduced by at least 2 points on 0-10 scale
Balances activity and rest throughout day

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate effective energy management strategies
indicators: Prioritizes activities based on energy levels
Modifies environment to reduce energy expenditure

interventions.title: Energy Management
actions: Determine causes of fatigue in collaboration with healthcare team
Assist patient to schedule activities for periods when energy levels are highest
Teach energy conservation techniques (sitting instead of standing, using assistive devices)
Implement planned rest periods between activities
Prioritize activities and eliminate non-essential tasks
Monitor nutritional and fluid intake
rationales: Addressing underlying causes may reduce fatigue
Scheduling activities during peak energy times improves performance
Energy conservation techniques reduce unnecessary energy expenditure
Planned rest prevents exhaustion and promotes recovery
Prioritization ensures essential activities are completed
Adequate nutrition and hydration support energy production
specialConsiderations: Adjust interventions based on underlying cause of fatigue
Consider cultural factors that may influence rest/activity patterns

interventions.title: Sleep Enhancement
actions: Establish consistent sleep-wake schedule
Create restful environment (reduce noise, adjust lighting, comfortable temperature)
Limit caffeine, alcohol, and nicotine, especially before bedtime
Teach relaxation techniques to use before sleep
Discourage daytime napping if it interferes with night sleep
Recommend light physical activity during the day
rationales: Consistent schedule helps regulate circadian rhythms
Environmental modifications promote sleep initiation and maintenance
Stimulants and depressants disrupt sleep quality
Relaxation techniques reduce anxiety and promote sleep onset
Excessive daytime napping can disrupt nighttime sleep
Physical activity promotes better sleep quality

expectedOutcomes: Reports decreased fatigue on standardized scale
Participates more in self-care and desired activities
Demonstrates use of energy conservation techniques
Plans activities based on energy levels
Modifies environment to reduce energy demands

title: Risk for Infection Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for preventing infection in at-risk patients, focusing on identification of risk factors, implementation of preventive measures, and early detection of infection signs.

assessments.title: Risk Factor Assessment
points: Identify presence of invasive devices (IV lines, urinary catheters, drains)
Assess integrity of skin and mucous membranes
Evaluate nutritional status and hydration
Assess immune function and presence of immunosuppression
Evaluate laboratory values (WBC count, neutrophil count, inflammatory markers)
assessments.description: Comprehensive risk assessment identifies factors that increase infection susceptibility and guides preventive interventions

assessments.title: Wound/Incision Assessment
points: Assess wound characteristics (appearance, drainage, odor)
Measure wound dimensions if applicable
Evaluate for signs of infection (redness, warmth, swelling, pain)
Assess surrounding tissue condition
Document wound healing progress
assessments.description: Regular wound assessment helps detect early signs of infection and evaluate healing progress

assessments.title: Systemic Assessment
points: Monitor vital signs including temperature q4h and PRN
Assess for systemic signs of infection (fever, chills, malaise)
Evaluate respiratory status for signs of respiratory infection
Assess urinary characteristics for signs of UTI
Monitor for signs of line-related infections at insertion sites
assessments.description: Systemic assessment helps detect early signs of infection before progression to serious complications

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Risk for Infection related to inadequate primary defenses, invasive procedures, and immunosuppression
relatedFactors: Inadequate primary defenses (broken skin, traumatized tissue)

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Risk for Impaired Skin Integrity related to external factors as evidenced by mechanical factors and moisture

goals.statement: Patient will remain free from signs and symptoms of infection
indicators: No purulent drainage from wounds or invasive device sites
No redness, warmth, or swelling at potential infection sites
No signs of systemic inflammatory response

goals.statement: Patient/caregiver will demonstrate knowledge of infection prevention measures
indicators: Describes signs and symptoms of infection to report
Demonstrates proper care of invasive devices if applicable
Describes appropriate wound care techniques if applicable

interventions.title: Infection Protection
actions: Implement standard precautions and additional transmission-based precautions as indicated
Perform hand hygiene before and after patient contact
Maintain aseptic technique during procedures and dressing changes
Assess and care for invasive device sites according to protocol
Administer prophylactic antibiotics if prescribed
Ensure proper environmental cleaning
rationales: Standard precautions prevent transmission of infectious agents
Hand hygiene is the most effective method to prevent infection transmission
Aseptic technique prevents introduction of pathogens
Regular site care prevents device-related infections
Prophylactic antibiotics may prevent infection in high-risk situations
Environmental cleanliness reduces pathogen reservoirs
specialConsiderations: Implement neutropenic precautions for severely immunocompromised patients
Consider private room for patients at high risk of infection or colonized with resistant organisms

interventions.title: Wound Care
actions: Perform wound care using aseptic technique
Clean wounds with appropriate solutions as prescribed
Apply dressings that maintain moist wound environment while absorbing excess drainage
Change dressings according to protocol or when soiled/saturated
Monitor wound healing progress
Protect intact skin around wounds
rationales: Aseptic technique prevents wound contamination
Appropriate cleaning removes debris without damaging tissue
Moist wound environment promotes healing while managing exudate
Timely dressing changes prevent maceration and contamination
Monitoring detects complications early
Protecting periwound skin prevents further breakdown
interventions.frequency: As prescribed or per facility protocol

evaluations.statement: Has patient remained free from infection?
expectedOutcomes: No signs of localized infection at wound or device sites

evaluations.statement: Does patient/caregiver demonstrate knowledge of infection prevention?
expectedOutcomes: Accurately describes signs of infection to report
Demonstrates proper technique for wound care if applicable

title: Impaired Physical Mobility Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for patients with impaired physical mobility, focusing on maintaining joint function, preventing complications, and maximizing independence in mobility.

assessments.title: Mobility Assessment
points: Assess range of motion of all joints
Evaluate muscle strength using 0-5 scale
Assess gait pattern and stability
Evaluate transfer ability and need for assistance
Assess balance while sitting and standing
Evaluate endurance during mobility activities
assessments.description: Comprehensive mobility assessment establishes baseline function and guides intervention planning

assessments.title: Risk Assessment
points: Assess for pressure injury risk using Braden Scale or similar tool
Evaluate risk for venous thromboembolism
Assess for contracture development
Evaluate respiratory status related to immobility
Assess for orthostatic hypotension with position changes
assessments.description: Risk assessment identifies potential complications of impaired mobility that require preventive interventions

assessments.title: Functional Assessment
points: Evaluate ability to perform ADLs independently
Assess need for assistive devices
Evaluate home environment for accessibility
Assess caregiver availability and ability
Determine prior level of function and mobility goals
assessments.description: Functional assessment helps establish realistic goals and identify needed supports for discharge planning

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Impaired Physical Mobility related to decreased muscle strength, pain, and musculoskeletal impairment as evidenced by limited range of motion and difficulty turning or repositioning
Risk for Disuse Syndrome related to physical immobility

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate improved mobility within limitations of condition
indicators: Demonstrates safe use of assistive devices

goals.statement: Patient will remain free from complications of immobility
indicators: Skin remains intact without pressure injuries

interventions.title: Exercise Therapy: Joint Mobility
actions: Perform passive range of motion exercises for immobile patients
Assist with active range of motion exercises as tolerated
Implement progressive mobility protocol (dangling, standing, ambulation)
Apply splints or positioning devices as prescribed
Encourage frequent position changes at least every 2 hours
Consult physical therapy for specialized exercise program
rationales: Range of motion exercises prevent contractures and maintain joint function
Active exercises improve strength and endurance
Progressive mobility prevents deconditioning and complications
Splints maintain functional position and prevent deformity
Position changes prevent pressure injuries and promote circulation
Physical therapy provides specialized expertise for mobility rehabilitation
specialConsiderations: Modify exercises based on patient's pain level and tolerance
Consider cultural factors that may influence mobility practices

interventions.title: Transfer Technique
actions: Assess for appropriate transfer method (stand-pivot, sliding board, mechanical lift)
Ensure adequate staff assistance for safe transfers
Teach patient proper body mechanics for transfers
Use transfer aids as appropriate (gait belt, slide sheets)
Provide verbal cues and guidance during transfers
Document transfer status and assistance required
rationales: Appropriate transfer method ensures safety for patient and staff
Adequate assistance prevents falls and injury
Proper body mechanics reduce strain and promote independence
Transfer aids reduce friction and shearing forces
Verbal cues enhance learning and participation
Documentation ensures consistency in approach

expectedOutcomes: Requires less assistance with transfers and ambulation
Uses assistive devices correctly and safely
Participates more actively in mobility activities

evaluations.statement: Has patient remained free from complications of immobility?
expectedOutcomes: No signs or symptoms of venous thromboembolism
Maintains or improves joint range of motion
Maintains clear lung sounds and adequate oxygenation

title: Deficient Knowledge Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for addressing knowledge deficits related to health conditions, treatments, and self-care, focusing on effective teaching strategies and evaluation of learning outcomes.

assessments.title: Learning Needs Assessment
points: Assess current knowledge level regarding condition and treatment
Evaluate health literacy using standardized tool
Identify patient's learning style (visual, auditory, kinesthetic)
Assess barriers to learning (language, cognitive limitations, sensory deficits)
Determine patient's priorities and concerns regarding learning needs
assessments.description: Comprehensive learning assessment helps tailor educational interventions to patient's needs and abilities

assessments.title: Readiness to Learn Assessment
points: Evaluate emotional readiness to receive information
Assess motivation and perceived importance of learning
Evaluate attention span and concentration ability
Assess for pain, fatigue, or other physical barriers to learning
Identify optimal time of day for teaching sessions
assessments.description: Readiness assessment helps identify the optimal timing and approach for educational interventions

assessments.title: Support System Assessment
points: Identify key family members or caregivers involved in patient's care
Assess caregiver knowledge and learning needs
Evaluate home environment for implementation of new knowledge
Assess financial resources for obtaining necessary supplies or medications
Identify community resources available to support learning and self-care
assessments.description: Support system assessment helps identify additional learners and resources to reinforce education

interventions.title: Teaching: Disease Process
actions: Assess current knowledge and understanding of condition
Provide information about disease process, causes, and contributing factors
Explain relationship between disease and symptoms

Understanding disease process improves adherence to treatment
Connecting symptoms to disease improves recognition and reporting
Knowledge of complications promotes early intervention
Multiple methods address different learning styles
Appropriate literacy level improves comprehension and retention

specialConsiderations: Use interpreter services for non-English speaking patients

interventions.title: Teaching: Prescribed Medication
actions: Provide information about medication names, purposes, and doses
Explain administration techniques and timing
Discuss potential side effects and management strategies
Identify drug interactions and foods to avoid
Provide written medication schedule
Demonstrate and have patient return-demonstrate medication administration

Proper administration ensures therapeutic effect
Awareness of side effects promotes early recognition and management
Understanding interactions prevents adverse effects
Written schedules serve as memory aids
Return demonstration confirms understanding and ability

Identifies signs and symptoms requiring medical attention
Demonstrates understanding of follow-up care requirements

title: Activity Intolerance Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for patients experiencing activity intolerance, focusing on gradual activity progression, energy conservation, and addressing underlying physiological causes.

assessments.title: Activity Tolerance Assessment
points: Assess vital sign response to activity (heart rate, blood pressure, respiratory rate, oxygen saturation)
Evaluate subjective symptoms during activity (dyspnea, chest pain, dizziness, fatigue)
Assess duration and intensity of activity that produces symptoms
Evaluate recovery time after activity
Assess impact of activity intolerance on ADLs and quality of life
assessments.description: Comprehensive activity assessment establishes baseline tolerance and guides activity progression planning

assessments.title: Cardiopulmonary Assessment
points: Auscultate heart sounds for abnormalities
Assess lung sounds for crackles, wheezes, or decreased breath sounds
Evaluate for peripheral edema
Assess for signs of respiratory distress at rest and with activity
Review cardiac and pulmonary function tests if available
assessments.description: Cardiopulmonary assessment helps identify underlying physiological causes of activity intolerance

assessments.title: Functional Capacity Assessment
points: Determine baseline functional capacity using standardized tool (6-minute walk test, MET level)
Assess ability to perform ADLs independently
Evaluate need for assistive devices during activity
Assess home environment for barriers to activity
Determine prior level of function and activity goals
assessments.description: Functional assessment helps establish realistic goals and measure progress in activity tolerance

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Activity Intolerance related to imbalance between oxygen supply and demand as evidenced by abnormal heart rate or blood pressure response to activity and exertional dyspnea
relatedFactors: Imbalance between oxygen supply and demand
definingCharacteristics: Abnormal heart rate or blood pressure response to activity
ECG changes reflecting arrhythmias or ischemia

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Ineffective Breathing Pattern related to respiratory muscle fatigue as evidenced by dyspnea and altered chest excursion
definingCharacteristics: Use of accessory muscles to breathe

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate improved activity tolerance with stable vital signs during activity
indicators: Heart rate increases no more than 20 bpm above resting with activity
Blood pressure remains within 20 mmHg of baseline during activity
Respiratory rate returns to baseline within 3-5 minutes after activity
Reports decreased symptoms during equivalent activity

goals.statement: Patient will perform ADLs with minimal symptoms of activity intolerance
indicators: Completes self-care activities with minimal assistance
Reports fatigue level <3 on 0-10 scale after ADLs
Demonstrates use of energy conservation techniques

interventions.title: Activity Therapy
actions: Implement progressive activity protocol based on tolerance
Monitor vital signs before, during, and after activity
Schedule activities during periods of highest energy
Provide rest periods before and after activity
Administer oxygen therapy during activity if prescribed
Collaborate with physical therapy for individualized exercise program

Vital sign monitoring detects adverse responses to activity
Energy levels fluctuate throughout the day
Rest periods prevent excessive fatigue
Supplemental oxygen supports increased metabolic demands
Physical therapy provides specialized expertise for activity progression
specialConsiderations: Terminate activity if patient develops chest pain, severe dyspnea, dizziness, or pallor
Consider cardiac monitoring during initial activity trials for high-risk patients

interventions.title: Energy Management
actions: Teach energy conservation techniques (sitting instead of standing, using assistive devices)
Prioritize activities based on importance and energy requirements
Implement work simplification techniques
Arrange environment to minimize energy expenditure
Teach pursed-lip breathing during activity
Ensure adequate nutrition and hydration
rationales: Energy conservation techniques reduce unnecessary energy expenditure
Prioritization ensures essential activities are completed
Work simplification reduces energy demands
Environmental modifications reduce unnecessary movement
Pursed-lip breathing improves ventilation and reduces dyspnea
Proper nutrition and hydration support energy production

expectedOutcomes: Demonstrates increased duration and intensity of activity
Shows improved vital sign response to activity
Reports decreased symptoms with equivalent activity

evaluations.statement: Is patient effectively managing energy during activities?
expectedOutcomes: Demonstrates use of energy conservation techniques
Modifies environment to reduce energy demands
Reports less fatigue with daily activities

title: Acute Pain Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for managing acute pain, focusing on assessment, pharmacological and non-pharmacological interventions, and prevention of complications associated with pain and pain management.

assessments.title: Pain Assessment
points: Assess pain using appropriate scale (0-10 numeric, FACES, FLACC, etc.)
Evaluate pain characteristics (location, quality, radiation, timing, duration)
Assess aggravating and alleviating factors
Evaluate impact of pain on function, sleep, and mood
Assess for nonverbal indicators of pain
Reassess pain after interventions
assessments.description: Comprehensive pain assessment guides appropriate interventions and evaluates their effectiveness

assessments.title: Functional Assessment
points: Evaluate impact of pain on mobility and activities of daily living
Assess ability to perform deep breathing and coughing exercises
Evaluate effect of pain on sleep and rest
Assess impact on appetite and nutrition
Evaluate psychological response to pain (anxiety, fear, depression)
assessments.description: Functional assessment helps identify how pain affects recovery and guides holistic interventions

assessments.title: Medication Assessment
points: Review current analgesic regimen and effectiveness
Assess for side effects of pain medications
Evaluate risk factors for opioid-related adverse events
Assess patient's understanding of pain management plan
Evaluate for signs of tolerance, dependence, or aberrant medication behaviors
assessments.description: Medication assessment ensures safe and effective pharmacological pain management

Adjuvant medications enhance analgesia and reduce opioid requirements
Timely assessment determines intervention effectiveness
Proactive management of side effects improves adherence
Regimen adjustments ensure optimal pain control

interventions.title: Pain Management: Non-pharmacological

Teach and assist with relaxation techniques (deep breathing, guided imagery)
Implement position changes and proper body alignment
Provide distraction activities appropriate to age and preferences
Use therapeutic touch or massage if acceptable to patient
Ensure adequate rest periods between activities

Relaxation techniques reduce muscle tension and anxiety
Proper positioning reduces strain on painful areas
Distraction shifts focus away from pain
Touch and massage stimulate large nerve fibers and block pain transmission
Rest periods prevent pain exacerbation from fatigue

title: Risk for Shock Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for preventing and managing shock, focusing on early recognition of warning signs, hemodynamic monitoring, and prompt interventions to maintain tissue perfusion.

assessments.title: Hemodynamic Assessment
points: Monitor vital signs including blood pressure, heart rate, respiratory rate q15-30min
Assess for orthostatic hypotension if patient condition permits
Evaluate peripheral pulses (strength, equality, regularity)
Assess capillary refill time
Monitor central venous pressure (CVP) if central line present
Evaluate cardiac output/index if advanced monitoring available
assessments.description: Comprehensive hemodynamic assessment helps detect early signs of shock and guides resuscitation efforts

assessments.title: Tissue Perfusion Assessment
points: Assess skin color, temperature, and moisture
Evaluate level of consciousness and mental status
Monitor urine output hourly
Assess for mottling or cyanosis of extremities
Evaluate for delayed capillary refill (>3 seconds)
Monitor for changes in respiratory pattern
assessments.description: Tissue perfusion assessment helps identify end-organ hypoperfusion requiring immediate intervention

assessments.title: Laboratory Assessment
points: Monitor hemoglobin and hematocrit levels
Evaluate serum lactate levels
Assess arterial blood gases
Monitor electrolytes, particularly potassium and calcium
Evaluate coagulation studies
Monitor renal function tests
assessments.description: Laboratory assessment helps identify shock etiology, severity, and response to treatment

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Risk for Shock related to hypovolemia, infection, or cardiac dysfunction
Decreased Cardiac Output related to altered preload, afterload, or contractility as evidenced by hemodynamic instability

goals.statement: Patient will maintain adequate tissue perfusion as evidenced by stable vital signs and improved perfusion parameters
indicators: Blood pressure within patient's normal range or MAP >65 mmHg
Warm, dry skin with normal color

goals.statement: Patient will show resolution of shock state with normalization of laboratory values

interventions.title: Shock Management
actions: Establish and maintain patent airway
Administer oxygen therapy to maintain SpO2 >94%
Establish IV access with large-bore catheters (16-18 gauge)
Administer fluid resuscitation as prescribed
Position patient flat with legs elevated if hypovolemic shock suspected
Administer blood products as prescribed
Prepare for and assist with vasopressor administration if ordered
rationales: Patent airway ensures adequate oxygenation
Supplemental oxygen improves tissue oxygenation
Large-bore access allows rapid fluid administration
Fluid resuscitation restores intravascular volume
Trendelenburg position increases venous return
Blood products restore oxygen-carrying capacity
Vasopressors maintain perfusion pressure when fluids insufficient
specialConsiderations: Modify approach based on shock type (hypovolemic, cardiogenic, distributive, obstructive)
Consider central line placement for patients requiring multiple infusions or hemodynamic monitoring

interventions.title: Hemodynamic Monitoring
actions: Monitor vital signs q15min until stable, then q30-60min
Maintain continuous cardiac monitoring
Monitor urine output hourly
Assess peripheral perfusion q1-2h
Monitor CVP, pulmonary artery pressures, or cardiac output if available
Obtain laboratory studies as ordered (lactate, ABGs, CBC, electrolytes)
Document intake and output accurately
rationales: Frequent vital sign monitoring detects trends and response to treatment
Cardiac monitoring identifies dysrhythmias affecting cardiac output
Urine output reflects renal perfusion and volume status
Peripheral perfusion assessment detects changes in tissue perfusion
Advanced hemodynamic monitoring guides targeted therapy
Laboratory studies evaluate shock severity and response to treatment
I&O monitoring helps evaluate fluid balance

evaluations.statement: Has adequate tissue perfusion been maintained or restored?
expectedOutcomes: Warm, dry skin with normal color

evaluations.statement: Have laboratory values improved, indicating resolution of shock?

references.title: The Surviving Sepsis Campaign Bundle: 2018 update

notes: Consider early ICU transfer for patients with progressive shock despite initial interventions

title: Diarrhea Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for managing diarrhea, focusing on identifying causes, preventing complications, maintaining fluid and electrolyte balance, and promoting comfort and dignity.

assessments.title: Diarrhea Characteristics Assessment
points: Assess frequency, volume, consistency, and color of stools
Evaluate for presence of blood, mucus, or undigested food
Assess for associated symptoms (cramping, urgency, tenesmus)
Determine onset, duration, and pattern of diarrhea
Identify potential causes (medications, diet, infection, stress)
assessments.description: Detailed stool assessment helps identify potential causes and severity of diarrhea

assessments.title: Hydration and Electrolyte Assessment
points: Assess for signs of dehydration (dry mucous membranes, poor skin turgor, thirst)
Monitor vital signs including orthostatic blood pressure changes
Evaluate intake and output balance
Monitor weight daily
Assess laboratory values (electrolytes, BUN, creatinine)
assessments.description: Hydration assessment helps detect and prevent fluid and electrolyte imbalances associated with diarrhea

assessments.title: Skin Integrity Assessment
points: Assess perianal and perineal skin for irritation, breakdown, or excoriation
Evaluate for moisture-associated skin damage
Assess patient's ability to perform personal hygiene
Evaluate need for containment devices
Monitor for pressure injury risk in bedbound patients with diarrhea
assessments.description: Skin assessment helps prevent and detect complications related to frequent liquid stools

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Diarrhea related to infectious process, medication effects, or dietary factors as evidenced by frequent loose liquid stools
Risk for Deficient Fluid Volume related to active fluid loss as evidenced by diarrhea

goals.statement: Patient will experience reduction in frequency and volume of diarrhea
indicators: Decreased number of liquid stools per day

goals.statement: Patient will maintain adequate hydration and electrolyte balance
indicators: Stable vital signs without orthostatic changes

interventions.title: Diarrhea Management
actions: Identify and address underlying cause when possible
Administer antidiarrheal medications as prescribed
Implement appropriate diet modifications (BRAT diet, low-fiber, lactose-free)
Provide small, frequent
